overview: The purpose of this Act is to establish an adjudication system and procedures to process fireworks infractions. [1] It also amends and establishes various definitions and penalties for firework offenses, including establishing heightened penalties under certain circumstances, and establishes various criminal offenses and penalties related to fireworks or articles pyrotechnics. [1] The Act creates a dedicated adjudication system for fireworks infractions, similar to the existing traffic infraction system, to allow law enforcement agencies and the judiciary to quickly and efficiently process low-level cases. [1]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $ (HB1483_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [1] These funds are to carry out the purposes of this Act, including to update the judiciary information management system to implement the adjudications process established by section 2 of this Act. [1] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [1]
assumptions_and_methodology: The fiscal projections are based on the establishment of a new dedicated adjudication system for fireworks infractions, similar to the existing traffic infraction system. [1] Revenue calculations are based on new fees and fines, such as a $25 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fee for a permit to purchase and use consumer fireworks commonly known as firecrackers and a $110 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fee for aerial devices or display fireworks permits. [1] Additional revenue is based on new fines, including a $200 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fine for unlawfully purchasing or setting off consumer fireworks and fines for carriers ranging from $1,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) to $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt). [1]
agency_impact: This measure will impact the judiciary, which is tasked with expending appropriated funds and updating its information management system to implement the new adjudications process. [1] District court judges shall adjudicate fireworks infractions and will have powers including conducting hearings and imposing monetary assessments. [1] The prosecuting attorney will represent the state at trial, and law enforcement officers will issue notices of infraction. [1]
economic_impact: The legislature finds that the widespread use of illegal fireworks poses an extreme danger and lethal risk to public health and safety, resulting in fires, serious burn injuries, and fatalities. [1] This measure is intended to protect property from avoidable fire damage and the community from fire- and explosion-related injuries. [1] The bill imposes various fines, such as a penalty of no less than $500 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for certain violations, and establishes permit fees. [1]
policy_impact: This Act establishes a new chapter in the Hawaii Revised Statutes for the adjudication of fireworks infractions, which will be applied uniformly throughout the State and in all counties. [1] It amends numerous sections of Chapter 132D, Hawaii Revised Statutes, by adding and amending definitions, establishing new criminal offenses, and creating a continuum of enforcement mechanisms with graduated penalties. [1] The bill confers concurrent jurisdiction on district courts to hear and dispose of cases of fireworks infractions by children. [1]
revenue_sources: The bill appropriates funds out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [1] Additional revenues will be generated from fines and fees, such as a $25 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fee for consumer firework permits and a $110 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) fee for aerial device permits. [1] The court shall collect fines, and of the fines collected, shall pay twenty per cent to the State and eighty per cent to the county in which the fine was imposed. [1] In addition, the court shall impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction, which will be deposited into the judiciary computer system special fund. [1]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The bill appropriates an unspecified amount from general revenues for fiscal year 2025-2026 and the same sum for fiscal year 2026-2027. [1] This appropriation will be expended by the judiciary to update its information management system and implement the new adjudication process. [1] Ongoing revenues will be generated from various new fees and fines. [1] A permit for consumer fireworks known as firecrackers requires a fee of $25 (HB1483_.HTM.txt). [1] A permit for aerial devices, display fireworks, or articles pyrotechnic requires a fee of $110 (HB1483_.HTM.txt). [1] The court will impose an administrative fee of $20 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for each fireworks infraction where judgment is entered for the State. [1] Fines for carriers range from $1,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for a first offense to $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) for a third or subsequent offense. [1] Other violations are subject to a fine of no less than $500 (HB1483_.HTM.txt) and no more than $5,000 (HB1483_.HTM.txt). [1] Fines collected for violations of chapter 132D will be split, with eighty per cent going to the county for law enforcement purposes and twenty per cent to the State. [1] The long-term fiscal impact is indeterminate as it depends on the number of violations cited and adjudicated annually. [1]
